VOL. XXXI, No. 32
STONE TO SWIM AGAINST
ARMY IN FIRST MEET
OF SEASON
Ten Men to Make Trip to West Point;
Army Rules Strong Favorite;
Excels in Backstroke

Hopkins' hopes of making a creditable showing against Army Saturday were raised considerably last
Tuesday when it was announced
that Captain Stone will be able to
compete. Stone had been previously
reported as unable to swim because
of a severe attack of sinus trouble
and this coupled with the loss. of
Philip Lee, former Georgetown
University star, had dampened the
ardour of the Jay mermen. The
Hopkins captain was expected to resume practice last Tuesday at • the
Knights of Columbus pool. His return should assure Hopkins of a
place in the diving events and possibly in the backstroke: •

FEBRUARY 25 IS
DEADLINE FOR.DUES
.February 25 has been set as
a deadline for the payment of
senior class dues. If dues are
1101 in on this date it will be
impossible .for the management of the Hullabaloo to inchide their individual picture
and write-up in the year-book.
Any seniors who still wish
to have their picture inserted
m the annual may do so if they.
have their picture taken on or
before February 25.
Only approximately the
dues of twenty men are still
outstanding.
These
men
should pay their dues to Abrahams, Fennimore, or Bolton. .

AN OPPORTUNITY
Next Tuesday will witness the fifty-first Commemoration
Exercises of the University. Such an event needs no recommendation from the NEWS-LETTER. In common with every editor •
before us, we urge the undergraduates to attend. Officials of the
University have spent months in arranging a program which will
be impressive and interesting. Surely the student can forget the
daily grind of studies and activities for one day, and be present
at an event which will bring home to him, perhaps for the first
time, the importance and magnitude of his university.

DIME DIPLOMACY
Again we take our hats off to the Interfraternity Board.
It was generally thought that last year that august body, with its
quick convictions and dollar fines, had set a shining example of
what not to do. Last Monday, however, the members surpassed
themselves. They appear as loath to spend money for cups as
they were to collect it in the form of fines. In this effort to
rival the Coolidge administration in economy, all notions of fair
play and all sense of obligation seems to have been forgotten.
A few years ago the Board instituted an Interfraternity baseball tournament. The plan succeeded famously, and the tournament became an annual event. Not least among the factors in
the success of the idea was the silver loving cup presented each
year to the winning fraternity.
.Last year when the appointed time had rolled around the
baseball games were played as usual. Delta Gamma Theta put
out a nine which routfd all of Its rivals and won the championship together with a perfectly valid claim to the cup. The trophy,
however, was not forthcoming; the Board, perhaps, was in financial difficulty, having collected only two dollars in fines.
The delegates, proverbially open minded, did not want to see
baseball
victors cheated out of their cup; so last Monday they
the
proceeded to set matters right by voting them out of it in an
eminently legal manner. Since cups are expensive and since
the winner of two years ago naturally refused to give up its trophy,
the Board, prudent in money matters, wisely decided that, beginning with last year, there should be but one cup, which should
circulate from chapter house to chapter house until the end of
time.
If the ruling were to go into effect this season, it might deserve commendation. But a retroactive ruling which deprives a
fraternity of a trophy they won honorably is another matter entirely. Sometime ago we spoke of the "dollar diplomacy" of the
Interfraternity Board;'now, it seems, they have shifted their attention to even smaller denominations.

THE NEWS-LETTER

MAILBAG
THOSE GENTLE SOLDIERS
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
Critics of the R. 0. T. C. have
seized the opportunity presented by
the Frederick Y. M. C. A. conference's hostile resolution to again try
to blackball and belittle the former
organization. To call the R. 0. T.
C. militaristic is patently ridiculous;
on the contrary, the object of the
military training at this University,
as expressed by the Hopkins professors of military science and by the
representative of the Third Corps
Area at the military exercises last
spring is to create a strong enough
reserve force to make aggressive nations chary of attacking the United
States.
Furthermore, it has always been
the object of the R. 0. T. C. to
train into its members an antipathy
to all war and a realization that
they themselves will be the first to
fall in such a war. "We do not
want war" is the constant cry.
In addition to giving training in
patriotism—particularly respect for
the flag, national anthem, etc.—the
course in military training affords
exercise and disciplinary training
for the men. A far greater good
comes to the latter from marching
in a prescribed manner than from
walking in a haphazard fashion.
Opportunities for leadership are
given to all men who show talent
after the completion of the first

There is a quaint tradition extant among our authorities, to
the effect that there shall be no smoking in the corridors and classrooms of our various fire-proof buildings. One wonders at their
persistence in such a patently ridiculous ideal. Polite signs are
plastered throughout our otherwise dignified hall-ways; keennosed professors have traced the errant smoke-wisps of Camels,
Chesterfields, and the distinctly collegiate Lucky Strikes to their
innocent sources; the omnipresent decrepit janitor spends his peaceful hours reminding the undergraduate of rules;—and the undergraduate smokes
One reason for the stubbornness of the janitors may be contained in their unwillingness to soil their brooms.
No habitual smoker among Hopkins students ever leaves a

Telephone

J.

1

building merely for the purpose of catching a drag. He becomes
adept at palming his cigarette when passing Dr. Latane's office,
he learns to apprehend the moment of the janitor's shuffling appearance, and he makes a habit of opening the windows during
a quiz. Such interruptions to scholastic pursuits, however, as
that of a certain spectacled, puny, stupid Ethiope who broke in
on an English examination to enforce the law—such interruptions are inexcusable.
This moral obtuseness on the part of the students is not
merely an outgrowth of a general disapproval of rules and regulations. Rather, it indicates clearly the need of some loafing place,
to be enjoyed by the mass. For those who object to walking
through food, sitting on greasy papers; for any who detest the
messiness of spilled milk, melted ice-cream, or for those who lack
sufficient Hopkins spirit to enthuse over ghastly trophies of the
vintage of 1900, the loft of the Barn constitutes a sty rather than
a retreat. The fortunate "litterati" who compose the Tudor and
Stuart Club can escape to the undoubted refuge of their club
room; others are permitted to descend to the post-office; but there
is no smoking-room for the rest of the rabble
Do Y. M. C.
A. men smoke? I've never seen one so doing, even in Gilman
.Hall, where everyone smokes. It must certainly be arranged
beforehand that the undergraduate may do as he pleases in the
new "Y" building.
Just received a letter from some kind-hearted if mysterious
contributor who realizes the value of poetry as a space-filler.
To "Yes and No"—Some inquiry has been made by your
column as to what the students think about. Do you really think
they think? The majority is a mass of luke-warm morons with,
at most, three opinions: (1) the relative potency of Paul's gin
as compared with Light Lunch's,(2) the relative merits of Sarah's
line as compared with Sally's, and (3) the relative charms of the
choruses of "Lemaire's Affairs" and the "Scandals."
No one knows what the professors think. They seldom think
out loud, at any rate. ... Speaking of professors, the student body
doesn't know them nearly well enough. Advertising is needed.
Here's a swell lecture to sleep through:

year.

Even if Morton Hilmburger left
the R. 0. T. C. after the second
year, a few prominent men remained, among them the President
of the Junior Class and one of its
Student Council Representatives.
The decreased government appropriation makes it impossible for any
to be retained except the ones who
have shown the greatest proficiency.
The time and summer camp requirements also lead many men to withdraw after the second year.
As to Hamburger's charge that
the best men on the campus are not
R. 0. T. C. members, let me suggest that the Hopkins candidates
for the last Rhodes Scholarship
were both officers in the military
unit. The Evening Sun please note.
Very truly yours,
NORMAN B. GARDINER, JR.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 18, 1927
DR. FRENCH PICKS TWO
DEBATING TEAMS

Business Assistants
Appointed To Jay

O'Dunne, Niles and Bull Compose First
Team; Triangle Debate Arranged

Results of tryouts for the Johns
Hopkins Intercollegiate Debating
Team were announced today by Dr.
John Calvin French, adviser. The
results are as follows: Eugene
O'Dunne, chairman; Donald C.
Niles and Robert Bull, first team;
Norman Gardiner, chairman; Carey
Thompson and Irving Hoffman,
second team. Fenimore and Meyers
will serve as alternates, if necessary. The members are listed in accordance with their ability as rated
by Dr. French.
The schedule which is being completed will probably include debates
with Davison University, Wake
Forest College of North Carolina,
and William and Mary of Virginia
Debates with northern colleges will
also probably be arranged.
A triangle debate with Washington and Lee and University of
North Carolina will be held on May
6 in which both the first and second
teams will compete.

SWIMMERS MEET- ARMY
Continued from Page 1, Col. 1

this race. Finlay recently broke an
old academy record when he negotiated the distance in two minutes
flat. This is the Army's fifth meet
of the season, they having won two
in addition to the two losses cited
above.
In spite of the blows dealt their
hopes by Eddie Hill's sickness and
the loss of such promising candidates as Lee, who was to have been
the mainstay of the team, the Hopkins swimmers feel confident that
they will make a good showing in
this, their first meet of the year.

Harry Levine, M. D. Ghent, L.
A. Covell, C. Reider, and A. Bordley have been elected business assistants to the staff of the Black and
Blue Jay. The office of business
assistant has just recently been created and is designed to give credit
to non-staff members who contribute ads to the Jay. The campus
has always given credit to literary
contributors by printing their names
in the issue to which they have contributed and now business contributors will be recognized also.
The Jay is running a contest for
the member of the business staff doing the most for the magazine, the
prize being a trip to New York.
Harry B. Wolf, Jr., with $150 in
ads and much office work to his
credit; Richard Wood, with $600
in ads, and Samuel Hecht, with $800
in ads, are leading the race at the
present time.

TH E JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 18, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

E. E. ADAMS

ESTABLISHED 1818

NEWS
Provisions were recently made at
Lehigh University to insure a happy beginning of the second semester by the members of the Faculty.
A Faculty dance was held which
was unanimously pronounced a social success. Those not caring to
dance found amusement in several
rubbers of bridge and other card
games.
* * *
Twenty-six out of the twentyseven feminine secretaries at Northwestern University have organized
to combat the fraternities, whom
they claim control the campus politics. The young ladies appear to
be out for blood.
* *
An edict prohibiting dancing has
again been issued at Ohio Northern
University. Any student who is observed while indulging in such idle
amusement or any student organization, which gives a dance, is threatened with probable expulsion.
* * *
Three campus newspapers have
been issued in as many days at the
University of Manitoba. The trouble started when Leonard L. Knott,
.the editor of the Manitobian, the official student paper, was asked to resign by the faculty, as a result of
the time-worn question of the freedom of the press. A new staff was
elected to the Manitobian, while
Knott proceeded to establish a rival paper which he called the Manitoba Student. These two papers
appeared on successive days, and
on the third day the other publication appeared under the name of the
Red Herring, which contained libelous reports involving almost every
outstanding student at the University; and was printed in true fashion on bright red paper. It was finally disclosed that the students responsible were all members of the
Maninew editorial staff of
_ the
toban, who desired an anonymous
comeback at Knott, but unhappily
tried to bite off a good deal more
than they were able to masticate.
Necking parties and "guzzling" in
bootleggers' dives were among the
lurid accounts enclosed therein. To
date libel action has been threatened
by several students and the matter
has been laid in the hands of the
proper legal authorities.
* * *
A rather unique proposal has re cently been made by an alumnus of
Columbia University.- This loyal
son has inaugurated a movement to
have every alumnus of the institution leave one-tenth of his estate to
the University at his death. At
Present the movement does not apPear to be progressing very favorably.
* * *
Prizes of $500, $300, and $200
have been offered by Harper's Magaz:ine for the three best prose manuscripts written by undergraduates
in any of the American colleges or
Universities. Full information concerning the contest may be obtained
from Harper's Magazine, 49 East
33rd Street, New York City. Thy
contest doses March 5.

DANCE TO BE HELD
MONDAY AT BELVEDERE
Due to a misunderstanding
with the Emerson Hotel in regard to the date there will be
no dance given by the Cotillon
Club tomorrow night. However, the Club will hold a
dance next Monday night at
the Belvedere Hotel from 9
to 1. Bob Iula and his orchestra will furnish the music and
the charge for admission will
be $1.50 for a couple or stag.

NEW VOLUMES ADDED TO
CLUB'S COLLECTION
Dr. Thayer Himself Brings Book for
Tudor-Stuart Library

A valuable addition to the library of the Tudor and Stuart Club
was made Monday evening when
Dr. William S. Thayer, Hopkins
professor emeritus of medicine, presented the club with a volume of
Marcus Aurelius on behalf of Lady
William Osler, who entrusted him
with the book when he was visiting in England recently.
The same evening Dr. Thayer
(rave a reading of a number of his
poems, including some recent delightful translations of several Russian verses, before an audience of
about thirty members of the club.
Dr. Thayer also commented on and
passed around three other books recently given the club.

Hopkins' hopes of making a creditable showing against Army Saturday were raised considerably last
Tuesday when it was announced
that Captain Stone will be able to
compete. Stone had been previously
reported as unable to swim because
of a severe attack of sinus trouble
and this coupled with the loss. of
Philip Lee, former Georgetown
University star, had dampened the
ardour of the Jay mermen. The
Hopkins captain was expected to resume practice last Tuesday at • the
Knights of Columbus pool. His return should assure Hopkins of a
place in the diving events and possibly in the backstroke: •

AN OPPORTUNITY
Next Tuesday will witness the fifty-first Commemoration
Exercises of the University. Such an event needs no recommendation from the NEWS-LETTER. In common with every editor •
before us, we urge the undergraduates to attend. Officials of the
University have spent months in arranging a program which will
be impressive and interesting. Surely the student can forget the
daily grind of studies and activities for one day, and be present
at an event which will bring home to him, perhaps for the first
time, the importance and magnitude of his university.

DIME DIPLOMACY
Again we take our hats off to the Interfraternity Board.
It was generally thought that last year that august body, with its
quick convictions and dollar fines, had set a shining example of
what not to do. Last Monday, however, the members surpassed
themselves. They appear as loath to spend money for cups as
they were to collect it in the form of fines. In this effort to
rival the Coolidge administration in economy, all notions of fair
play and all sense of obligation seems to have been forgotten.
A few years ago the Board instituted an Interfraternity baseball tournament. The plan succeeded famously, and the tournament became an annual event. Not least among the factors in
the success of the idea was the silver loving cup presented each
year to the winning fraternity.
.Last year when the appointed time had rolled around the
baseball games were played as usual. Delta Gamma Theta put
out a nine which routfd all of Its rivals and won the championship together with a perfectly valid claim to the cup. The trophy,
however, was not forthcoming; the Board, perhaps, was in financial difficulty, having collected only two dollars in fines.
The delegates, proverbially open minded, did not want to see
baseball
victors cheated out of their cup; so last Monday they
the
proceeded to set matters right by voting them out of it in an
eminently legal manner. Since cups are expensive and since
the winner of two years ago naturally refused to give up its trophy,
the Board, prudent in money matters, wisely decided that, beginning with last year, there should be but one cup, which should
circulate from chapter house to chapter house until the end of
time.
If the ruling were to go into effect this season, it might deserve commendation. But a retroactive ruling which deprives a
fraternity of a trophy they won honorably is another matter entirely. Sometime ago we spoke of the "dollar diplomacy" of the
Interfraternity Board;'now, it seems, they have shifted their attention to even smaller denominations.

MAILBAG
THOSE GENTLE SOLDIERS
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
Critics of the R. 0. T. C. have
seized the opportunity presented by
the Frederick Y. M. C. A. conference's hostile resolution to again try
to blackball and belittle the former
organization. To call the R. 0. T.
C. militaristic is patently ridiculous;
on the contrary, the object of the
military training at this University,
as expressed by the Hopkins professors of military science and by the
representative of the Third Corps
Area at the military exercises last
spring is to create a strong enough
reserve force to make aggressive nations chary of attacking the United
States.
Furthermore, it has always been
the object of the R. 0. T. C. to
train into its members an antipathy
to all war and a realization that
they themselves will be the first to
fall in such a war. "We do not
want war" is the constant cry.
In addition to giving training in
patriotism—particularly respect for
the flag, national anthem, etc.—the
course in military training affords
exercise and disciplinary training
for the men. A far greater good
comes to the latter from marching
in a prescribed manner than from
walking in a haphazard fashion.
Opportunities for leadership are
given to all men who show talent

There is a quaint tradition extant among our authorities, to
the effect that there shall be no smoking in the corridors and classrooms of our various fire-proof buildings. One wonders at their
persistence in such a patently ridiculous ideal. Polite signs are
plastered throughout our otherwise dignified hall-ways; keennosed professors have traced the errant smoke-wisps of Camels,
Chesterfields, and the distinctly collegiate Lucky Strikes to their
innocent sources; the omnipresent decrepit janitor spends his peaceful hours reminding the undergraduate of rules;—and the undergraduate smokes
One reason for the stubbornness of the janitors may be contained in their unwillingness to soil their brooms.
No habitual smoker among Hopkins students ever leaves a

building merely for the purpose of catching a drag. He becomes
adept at palming his cigarette when passing Dr. Latane's office,
he learns to apprehend the moment of the janitor's shuffling appearance, and he makes a habit of opening the windows during
a quiz. Such interruptions to scholastic pursuits, however, as
that of a certain spectacled, puny, stupid Ethiope who broke in
on an English examination to enforce the law—such interruptions are inexcusable.
This moral obtuseness on the part of the students is not
merely an outgrowth of a general disapproval of rules and regulations. Rather, it indicates clearly the need of some loafing place,
to be enjoyed by the mass. For those who object to walking
through food, sitting on greasy papers; for any who detest the
messiness of spilled milk, melted ice-cream, or for those who lack
sufficient Hopkins spirit to enthuse over ghastly trophies of the
vintage of 1900, the loft of the Barn constitutes a sty rather than
a retreat. The fortunate "litterati" who compose the Tudor and
Stuart Club can escape to the undoubted refuge of their club
room; others are permitted to descend to the post-office; but there
is no smoking-room for the rest of the rabble
Do Y. M. C.
A. men smoke? I've never seen one so doing, even in Gilman
.Hall, where everyone smokes. It must certainly be arranged
beforehand that the undergraduate may do as he pleases in the
new "Y" building.
Just received a letter from some kind-hearted if mysterious
contributor who realizes the value of poetry as a space-filler.
To "Yes and No"—Some inquiry has been made by your
column as to what the students think about. Do you really think
they think? The majority is a mass of luke-warm morons with,
at most, three opinions: (1) the relative potency of Paul's gin
as compared with Light Lunch's,(2) the relative merits of Sarah's
line as compared with Sally's, and (3) the relative charms of the
choruses of "Lemaire's Affairs" and the "Scandals."
No one knows what the professors think. They seldom think
out loud, at any rate. ... Speaking of professors, the student body
doesn't know them nearly well enough. Advertising is needed.

Even if Morton Hilmburger left
the R. 0. T. C. after the second
year, a few prominent men remained, among them the President
of the Junior Class and one of its
Student Council Representatives.
The decreased government appropriation makes it impossible for any
to be retained except the ones who
have shown the greatest proficiency.
The time and summer camp requirements also lead many men to withdraw after the second year.
As to Hamburger's charge that
the best men on the campus are not
R. 0. T. C. members, let me suggest that the Hopkins candidates
for the last Rhodes Scholarship
were both officers in the military
unit. The Evening Sun please note.
Very truly yours,
NORMAN B. GARDINER, JR.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 18, 1927
DR. FRENCH PICKS TWO
DEBATING TEAMS

Business Assistants
Appointed To Jay

O'Dunne, Niles and Bull Compose First
Team; Triangle Debate Arranged

Results of tryouts for the Johns
Hopkins Intercollegiate Debating
Team were announced today by Dr.
John Calvin French, adviser. The
results are as follows: Eugene
O'Dunne, chairman; Donald C.
Niles and Robert Bull, first team;
Norman Gardiner, chairman; Carey
Thompson and Irving Hoffman,
second team. Fenimore and Meyers
will serve as alternates, if necessary. The members are listed in accordance with their ability as rated
by Dr. French.
The schedule which is being completed will probably include debates
with Davison University, Wake
Forest College of North Carolina,
and William and Mary of Virginia
Debates with northern colleges will
also probably be arranged.
A triangle debate with Washington and Lee and University of
North Carolina will be held on May
6 in which both the first and second
teams will compete.

Harry Levine, M. D. Ghent, L.
A. Covell, C. Reider, and A. Bordley have been elected business assistants to the staff of the Black and
Blue Jay. The office of business
assistant has just recently been created and is designed to give credit
to non-staff members who contribute ads to the Jay. The campus
has always given credit to literary
contributors by printing their names
in the issue to which they have contributed and now business contributors will be recognized also.
The Jay is running a contest for
the member of the business staff doing the most for the magazine, the
prize being a trip to New York.
Harry B. Wolf, Jr., with $150 in
ads and much office work to his
credit; Richard Wood, with $600
in ads, and Samuel Hecht, with $800
in ads, are leading the race at the
present time.

TH E JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 18, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

E. E. ADAMS

ESTABLISHED 1818

NEWS
Provisions were recently made at
Lehigh University to insure a happy beginning of the second semester by the members of the Faculty.
A Faculty dance was held which
was unanimously pronounced a social success. Those not caring to
dance found amusement in several
rubbers of bridge and other card
games.
* * *
Twenty-six out of the twentyseven feminine secretaries at Northwestern University have organized
to combat the fraternities, whom
they claim control the campus politics. The young ladies appear to
be out for blood.
* *
An edict prohibiting dancing has
again been issued at Ohio Northern
University. Any student who is observed while indulging in such idle
amusement or any student organization, which gives a dance, is threatened with probable expulsion.
* * *
Three campus newspapers have
been issued in as many days at the
University of Manitoba. The trouble started when Leonard L. Knott,
.the editor of the Manitobian, the official student paper, was asked to resign by the faculty, as a result of
the time-worn question of the freedom of the press. A new staff was
elected to the Manitobian, while
Knott proceeded to establish a rival paper which he called the Manitoba Student. These two papers
appeared on successive days, and
on the third day the other publication appeared under the name of the
Red Herring, which contained libelous reports involving almost every
outstanding student at the University; and was printed in true fashion on bright red paper. It was finally disclosed that the students responsible were all members of the
Maninew editorial staff of
_ the
toban, who desired an anonymous
comeback at Knott, but unhappily
tried to bite off a good deal more
than they were able to masticate.
Necking parties and "guzzling" in
bootleggers' dives were among the
lurid accounts enclosed therein. To
date libel action has been threatened
by several students and the matter
has been laid in the hands of the
proper legal authorities.
* * *
A rather unique proposal has re cently been made by an alumnus of
Columbia University.- This loyal
son has inaugurated a movement to
have every alumnus of the institution leave one-tenth of his estate to
the University at his death. At
Present the movement does not apPear to be progressing very favorably.
* * *
Prizes of $500, $300, and $200
have been offered by Harper's Magaz:ine for the three best prose manuscripts written by undergraduates
in any of the American colleges or
Universities. Full information concerning the contest may be obtained
from Harper's Magazine, 49 East
33rd Street, New York City. Thy
contest doses March 5.

DANCE TO BE HELD
MONDAY AT BELVEDERE
Due to a misunderstanding
with the Emerson Hotel in regard to the date there will be
no dance given by the Cotillon
Club tomorrow night. However, the Club will hold a
dance next Monday night at
the Belvedere Hotel from 9
to 1. Bob Iula and his orchestra will furnish the music and
the charge for admission will
be $1.50 for a couple or stag.

NEW VOLUMES ADDED TO
CLUB'S COLLECTION
Dr. Thayer Himself Brings Book for
Tudor-Stuart Library

A valuable addition to the library of the Tudor and Stuart Club
was made Monday evening when
Dr. William S. Thayer, Hopkins
professor emeritus of medicine, presented the club with a volume of
Marcus Aurelius on behalf of Lady
William Osler, who entrusted him
with the book when he was visiting in England recently.
The same evening Dr. Thayer
(rave a reading of a number of his
poems, including some recent delightful translations of several Russian verses, before an audience of
about thirty members of the club.
Dr. Thayer also commented on and
passed around three other books recently given the club.

High school men, active in both
athletic and non-athletic organizations, will be invited. According to

correspondent of the Club, the object of the smoker is to have the

contact with Hopkins undergraduates. In an attempt to create such
a friendly relation, prominent officers of the important campus organizations have also been asked to
attend.
At a meeting of the Varsity Club
on Wednesday, Dr. Ray van Orman told members that the main
purpose of the proposed smoker is
to influence men prominent in prep
school affairs to come to Hopkins.
